hacking.title: Computer Hacking
hacking.description: Unauthorized access to computer systems or networks with the intent to cause damage, steal data, or commit other cybercrimes.

legal_framework.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years or fine up to 5 lakh rupees or both

relevant_sections.individual_victims: Section 66 of the Information Technology Act
relevant_sections.corporate_victims: Section 66 with Section 43A for compensation from body corporate

individual: Preserve evidence by taking screenshots and saving logs
Document incident timeline with specific details
File a complaint at the local police station or cyber crime portal (cybercrime.gov.in)
Provide all relevant details including timeline of the incident
Report to CERT-In if major system compromise
corporate: Preserve digital evidence and system logs
Document breach timeline and affected systems
Mandatory reporting to CERT-In within 6 hours
File formal police complaint with cyber cell

landmark_cases.name: State vs Amit Tiwari (2016)
landmark_cases.significance: Established standards for digital evidence collection in hacking cases

landmark_cases.name: Shreya Singhal vs Union of India (2015)
landmark_cases.significance: Clarified scope of Section 66A (now struck down) vs Section 66

prevention_tips: Implement strong password policies
Enable two-factor authentication
Keep systems and software updated
Use firewalls and intrusion detection systems
Conduct regular security audits

phishing.title: Phishing Attacks
phishing.description: Fraudulent attempt to obtain sensitive information such as usernames, passwords, and credit card details by disguising as a trustworthy entity.

legal_framework.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years and fine up to 1 lakh rupees

relevant_sections.impersonation: Section 66D - Punishment for cheating by personation

individual: Do not respond to suspicious communications
Save all evidence including email headers
Report to cyber crime portal (cybercrime.gov.in)
Notify bank/financial institution if financial information was compromised
File a police complaint with all evidence attached
corporate: Report to IT security team immediately
Preserve original phishing communication with headers
Report to financial institutions if credentials compromised
File official complaint with cyber cell

landmark_cases.name: Indian Bank vs Cyber Cell (2018)
landmark_cases.significance: Established bank's responsibility in preventing phishing attacks

landmark_cases.name: State of Maharashtra vs Rizwan Khan (2019)
landmark_cases.significance: Major phishing ring prosecution setting precedent for organized cybercrime

prevention_tips: Verify sender email addresses carefully
Never click suspicious links or download unexpected attachments
Check for HTTPS and security certificates
Use email filtering and anti-phishing tools
Implement employee awareness training

online_harassment.title: Online Harassment
online_harassment.description: Use of electronic communications to harass, threaten, or intimidate a person, typically by sending messages of an intimidating or threatening nature.

primary_sections: Section 67 of IT Act, Section 354D of IPC
legal_framework.punishment: Section 67: Up to 3 years and fine; Section 354D: Up to 3 years for first conviction

relevant_sections.general_harassment: Section 67 of IT Act - Publication of obscene material
relevant_sections.women_children: Sections 67A and 67B of IT Act for aggravated cases

individual: Block the harasser on all platforms
Document all incidents with date, time, and screenshots
Report to platform where harassment occurred
File complaint with cyber crime cell providing all evidence
In severe cases, seek restraining order
law_enforcement: Record victim statement with specific incident details
Collect all digital evidence including platform reports
Trace origin of messages through platform cooperation
Document pattern of behavior if repeated incidents
Consider psychological impact assessment in severe cases

landmark_cases.name: Yogesh Prajapati vs State (2021)
landmark_cases.significance: Expanded definition of online stalking to include multiple platform harassment

landmark_cases.name: Swati Sharma vs Facebook India (2020)
landmark_cases.significance: Established platform responsibility in addressing harassment complaints

prevention_tips: Use privacy settings on social media platforms
Limit personal information shared online
Be cautious about connection requests from strangers
Document any concerning behavior from early stages
Familiarize yourself with platform reporting tools

identity_theft.title: Identity Theft
identity_theft.description: Fraudulent acquisition and use of a person's private identifying information, usually for financial gain.

legal_framework.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years and fine up to 1 lakh rupees

relevant_sections.financial_fraud: Section 66C with provisions of IPC Section 420 for cheating

individual: Inform financial institutions immediately
Change passwords on all accounts
Place fraud alert with credit bureaus
File complaint with cyber crime portal with all evidence
Monitor credit reports regularly after incident
law_enforcement: Document complete timeline of identity misuse
Collect financial transaction history and fraud attempts
Coordinate with financial institutions for records
Request IP logs from platforms where identity was misused
Establish chain of custody for all digital evidence

evidence_collection: Screenshots of fake profiles or accounts
Communication with financial institutions reporting fraud

landmark_cases.name: State Bank of India vs Unknown (2017)
landmark_cases.significance: Established bank liability in cases of inadequate KYC verification

landmark_cases.name: Rahul Mehta vs Cyber Cell Delhi (2018)
landmark_cases.significance: Set precedent for comprehensive damages in identity theft cases

prevention_tips: Use strong, unique passwords for different accounts
Enable two-factor authentication where available
Regularly monitor financial statements
Be cautious about sharing personal information online
Consider identity theft protection services

data_breach.title: Data Breach
data_breach.description: A security incident in which sensitive, protected or confidential data is copied, transmitted, viewed, stolen or used by an unauthorized individual.

primary_sections: Section 43A and Section 72A of IT Act, 2000
legal_framework.punishment: Section 43A: Compensation to affected person; Section 72A: Up to 2 years or fine up to 1 lakh rupees or both

relevant_sections.negligence: Section 43A - Compensation for failure to protect data
relevant_sections.breach_of_contract: Section 72A - Disclosure of information in breach of lawful contract

individual: Report to organization that experienced the breach
Document all compromised information
Monitor accounts for suspicious activity
File complaint with cyber crime portal
Consider credit freeze if financial information exposed
corporate: Mandatory reporting to CERT-In within 6 hours of discovery
Notify affected individuals with remediation steps
Implement security improvements to prevent recurrence

landmark_cases.name: HDFC Bank Data Breach (2019)
landmark_cases.significance: Established compensatory framework for financial data breaches

landmark_cases.name: Air India vs CERT-In (2021)
landmark_cases.significance: Clarified timely reporting requirements for large-scale data breaches

prevention_tips: Implement data encryption for sensitive information
Regularly update security protocols and software
Conduct periodic security assessments
Train employees on data handling best practices
Develop and test incident response plan

patterns: I want to file a complaint
responses: To report a cybercrime, you can file a complaint on the National Cyber Crime Reporting Portal (cybercrime.gov.in) or visit your local police station. Could you tell me what type of cybercrime you're dealing with so I can provide specific guidance?
Cybercrime reporting in India can be done through the cybercrime.gov.in portal or at your local police station's cyber cell. What specific incident are you looking to report?

For reporting cybercrimes, preserve all evidence first (screenshots, logs, emails), then file a complaint on cybercrime.gov.in or visit your local cyber cell. Would you like specific reporting steps for a particular type of cybercrime?
Punishment for cybercrimes in India varies based on the specific offense. Could you tell me which cybercrime you're asking about so I can provide the exact penalties under the IT Act?
Under the IT Act, cybercrimes carry various penalties ranging from imprisonment of 2-3 years to fines of 1-5 lakh rupees depending on the offense. Which specific crime are you inquiring about?

Legal consequences for cybercrimes typically include imprisonment and/or fines, with severity based on the nature of the offense. For specific penalty details, please specify which cybercrime you're interested in.

children_protection.special_provisions: Sections 67B of IT Act specifically addresses child pornography and exploitation
children_protection.enhanced_penalties: Imprisonment up to 5 years and fine up to 10 lakh rupees for first conviction
children_protection.reporting: Mandatory reporting to National Cyber Crime Reporting Portal and National Commission for Protection of Child Rights

critical_infrastructure.special_provisions: Information Technology (Critical Information Infrastructure Protection) Rules, 2018
critical_infrastructure.reporting_requirements: Immediate reporting to CERT-In and National Critical Information Infrastructure Protection Centre (NCIIPC)
critical_infrastructure.enhanced_security: Mandatory security audits and designated Chief Information Security Officer
